intro: Potentilla maculata var. vulgaris, commonly known as the spotted knapweed, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces clusters of small, yellow flowers arranged in a spherical inflorescence, which bloom in late summer. Its leaves are heart-shaped, with a distinctive white or pale purple marking on the underside. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soils, often found in meadows and along roadsides.
